) A third-party authorization is a signed document and/or an oral statement made by a taxpayer granting speciﬁc authorities to a third-party. Third-party and authorizations include: • Form
, Power of Attorney and Declaration of Representative, • Form
, Tax Information Authorization, • Form

, United States Estate (and Generation-Skipping Transfer) Return, • Oral Disclosure Consent (ODC), a non-written tax information tion, or • Third-Party Designee (also known as Check-box authority). These authorizations may be submitted through paper submission via fax or mail or taxpayer contact directly with the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) for oral authorizations. (
) The Check-box authority election is made directly on the tax Form and is not recorded on the Centralized Authorization File (CAF). See IRM
, Third-Party Designee Authentication. (

) Types of authorization authority are: • Representative - An individual the taxpayer has authorized to the taxpayer before the IRS. • Designee - An individual person or business entity the taxpayer appoints to receive and inspect conﬁdential tax return information or in writing for the type of tax and years or periods speciﬁed by the taxpayer. • Third-Party Designee - An individual person that has been to receive and inspect conﬁdential tax return information via or Check-box election on a tax return. (

) Taxpayers have the right to retain an authorized representative of their to represent them in dealings with the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). Taxpayers have the right to be told that if they cannot afford to hire a tative, they may be eligible for assistance from a Low-Income Taxpayer (

) The Centralized Authorization File (CAF) is a computerized system of which houses authorization information from both powers of attorney and tax information authorizations. The CAF system contains several types of among them taxpayer and representative’s records, tax modules and zations. (

) The CAF contains: • Taxpayer name, Taxpayer Identiﬁcation Number (TIN), name control signature date • Third-Party name, address, telephone number, fax number, name control, CAF number and status information • Type of tax e.g., (MFT)(s) and tax period(s) • Employee Plan number, if applicable • Source Document Locator Number (SDLN) • Authorization type, e.g., Form
, Form
, Form
etc. • Representation designation level(s), e.g., A - Attorney, B - Certiﬁed Public Accountant (CPA), etc. (

(1) Taxpayer Digital Communication (TDC) Platform allows authorization informa- tion from both powers of attorney and tax information authorizations to be Digital submitted by practitioners who represent their client via this online service. (TDC) Practitioners who use this system will have the capabilities to submit authoriza- Overview tions on Form 2848 and Form 8821.The eGain system in CAF will be used to process these authorizations submitted by practitioners via secure messaging in the TDC Platform. Access to eGain requires a request via BEARS . (2) Electronic signatures appear in many forms. Acceptable electronic signature methods include: • A typed name that is typed into the signature block • A scanned or digitized image of a handwritten signature that is attached to an electronic record • A handwritten signature input onto an electronic signature pad or • A handwritten signature, mark, or command input on a display screen with a stylus device. (3) Only certain ﬁle types can be uploaded to the TDC system and there is a limi- tation on the ﬁle size. Acceptable File Types and ﬁle size limits: • 15MB ﬁle size limit • .pdf, .jpeg, .jpg, .gif ﬁle formats (4) Authorizations received in the TDC platform do not change the IRM proce- dures. The same procedure for paper authorizations are followed when controlling a case or determining the validity of the authorization in this system.

The Inbox/List pane holds a great deal of information, of which there are multiple layers you can navigate to get down to speciﬁc details. This is starting destination when you sign into the Advisor Desktop. Any activities pulled or that have been assigned to you, will be in your inbox. ) The Ellipsis (more menu) is three vertical dots in the upper right of the When a user clicks on the ellipsis a drop-down menu displays the following options: • Refresh – Refreshes the information in the user’s inbox. • Pull – Allows the user to pull cases from a queue. • Pick – Allows the user to manually select activities to pull into their inbox list. Depending on the permissions given by the administrator, user may be able to select activities from a speciﬁc department, or user. • Transfer – Transfer a selected activity. Depending on the given by the administrator, the user may be able to transfer activities from a speciﬁc department, queue, or user. • Set Status – Not used in CAF. • Pin/Unpin – This option pins or unpins the selected activity to allow other users from pulling the activity. • Notes – This option opens the Notes window, it can be used to view existing notes attached to a case. Also allows for input of new notes. • Layout – Defaults to Responsive view and contains a pull right (

Pin/Unpin – This option pins or unpins the selected activity to allow other users from pulling the activity. Notes – This option opens the Notes window, it can be used to view existing notes attached to a case. Also allows for input of new notes.
